comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
On October 19, President Woodrow Wilson rode in a private railroad car to Princeton, New Jersey, his nominal home town, and legal voting place. He arrived with his new (second) wife, Edith Bolling Galt Wilson, went to the polling place and voted "yes" on the Woman Suffrage Amendment, then left after being in town for only an hour and a half. This paragraph appeared the next day in the Daily Princetonian:

PRESIDENT WILSON HERE; VOTES "YES" FOR SUFFRAGE
President Woodrow Wilson yesterday made his second visit to Princeton since college opened. His private car arrived at about 12.20, and he proceeded at once to the seventh district polls in the house of Engine Company No. 3 00 Chambers Street. After voting, the President paid a visit to Professor W. U. Vreeland, and later to Dean Fine. He left Princeton at 1.45 p. m.

comment.author: 68565681@N00
comment._content: The tracks ran all the way uphill to Nassau Street in those days, near where Holder and Hamilton halls are today. I wonder if the picture was shot near there.

comment._content: Thanks Wystan for your research. We will add some information to the record the next time we update.
